name: Query
overview:
This class allows you interact with Cloud Datastore.

First, install @google-cloud/datastore with npm:

$ npm install --save @google-cloud/datastore

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to @google-cloud/datastoreâ€” we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Google Cloud Platform

var datastore = require('@google-cloud/datastore')();

Elsewhere

var datastore = require('@google-cloud/datastore')({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to @google-cloud/datastore are outlined in our Authentication guide.

methods.name: Query
methods.description:
Build a Query object.

Queries are built with datastore#createQuery and transaction#createQuery.

methods.name: filter
methods.description:
Datastore allows querying on properties. Supported comparison operators are =, <, >, <=, and >=. "Not equal" and IN operators are currently not supported.

To filter by ancestors, see datastore/query#hasAncestor.

examples.caption: List all companies that are located in California.
List all companies named Google that have less than 400 employees.
To filter by key, use __key__ for the property name. Filter on keys stored as properties is not currently supported.
examples.code:
var key = datastore.key(['Company', 'Google']);
var keyQuery = query.filter('__key__', key);

methods.name: order
methods.description: Sort the results by a property name in ascending or descending order. By default, an ascending sort order will be used.

params.name: options.descending
params.description: • Sort the results by a property name in descending order. Default: false.

methods.name: groupBy
methods.description: Group query results by a list of properties.

methods.name: select
methods.description:
Retrieve only select properties from the matched entities.

Queries that select a subset of properties are called Projection Queries.

params.name: fieldNames
params.description: • Properties to return from the matched entities.

methods.name: start
methods.description: Set a starting cursor to a query.

methods.name: end
methods.description: Set an ending cursor to a query.

examples.code:
// Limit the results to 10 entities.
var limitQuery = companyQuery.limit(10);

params.name: n
params.description: • The number of results to limit the query to.

examples.code:
// Start from the 101st result.
var offsetQuery = companyQuery.offset(100);

params.name: n
params.description: • The offset to start from after the start cursor.

examples.caption: A keys-only query returns just the keys of the result entities instead of the entities themselves, at lower latency and cost.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options.consistency
params.description: • Specify either strong or eventual. If not specified, default values are chosen by Datastore for the operation. Learn more about strong and eventual consistency here.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function. If omitted, a readable stream instance is returned.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.info.endCursor
params.description: • Use this in a follow-up query to begin from where these results ended.

params.name: callback.info.moreResults
params.description:
• Datastore responds with one of:
    • datastore#MORE_RESULTS_AFTER_LIMIT: There may be more results after the specified limit.
    • datastore#MORE_RESULTS_AFTER_CURSOR: There may be more results after the specified end cursor.
    • datastore#NO_MORE_RESULTS: There are no more results.

methods.name: runStream
methods.description: Run the query as a readable object stream.

examples.caption: If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: options
params.description: • Optional configuration. See datastore/query#run for a complete list of options.
